A mix of fear, demagoguery and poor economic trouble would have lead the german people to place faith in a outsider, and with his twisted rhetoric he gave a simple answer to a complex problem. A racial answer nonetheless, and when race is brought into the equation of economic trouble it will always lead to violence.
There are some connections with today and the past, the rise of the far right, Le-pen, Brexit and the election of Donald Trump. While not all of these things have something to do with nazism. But they do with right-wing nationalism, Donald Trump and Brexit would be good examples.
How would we avoid these problems? Historical knowledge of events like this is extremely important but is not the only thing, otherwise this wouldn't be occurring.
Let's have a look at Trump's and Le-pen's voting base, the majority were poor white workers. France's socialists party failed them and democrats don't represent the workers. That's the probelm the parties we'rent helping poor to an extent where could feel secure. And when one doesn't feel secure and with no sense of choice, one would vote for an outsider.
But there is a flipside to this, people voting for candidates like Bernie Sanders, Jeremy Corbyn shows that people are sick of being the victims of economic neoliberalism. But if the left doesn't organise to the extent as the right has history might repeat itself.
But I am just one person, let me hear your opinions, Khan Academy and youtube comentors?
